steps.title: Look at the equation.
steps.content: Look at the equation. If you plan to use this method, the equation should follow a basic format of: ax 2 + bx + c. [1] X Research source This process is usually used when the leading coefficient (the a term) is a number other than "1," but it can also be used for quadratic equations in which a = 1 . Example: 2x 2 + 9x + 10

steps.title: Find the master product.
steps.content: Find the master product . Multiply the a term and c term together. The product of these two terms is referred to as the master product . [2] X Research source Example: 2x 2 + 9x + 10 a = 2; c = 10 a * c = 2 * 10 = 20

steps.title: Separate the master product into its factor pairs.
steps.content: Separate the master product into its factor pairs. List the factors of your master product, separating them into their natural pairs (the pairs required to produced the master product). [3] X Research source Example: The factors of 20 are: 1, 2, 4, 5, 10, 20 Written in factor pairs: (1, 20), (2, 10), (4, 5)

steps.title: Find a factor pair with a sum equal to b.
steps.content: Find a factor pair with a sum equal to b . Look through the factor pairs and determine which set will produce the b term—the middle term and the coefficient of x —when added together. [4] X Research source If your master product was negative, you will need to find a pair of factors that equal the b term when subtracted from one another. Example: 2x 2 + 9x + 10 b = 9 1 + 20 = 21; this is not the correct pair 2 + 10 = 12; this is not the correct pair 4 + 5 = 9; this is the correct pair

steps.title: Split the center term into the two factors.
steps.content: Split the center term into the two factors. Rewrite the center term, breaking it apart into the factor pair previously identified. Make sure that you include the proper signs (plus or minus). [5] X Research source Note that the order of the center terms should not matter for this problem. No matter which order you write the terms in, the end result should be the same. Example: 2x 2 + 9x + 10 = 2x 2 + 5x + 4x + 10

steps.title: Group the terms to form pairs.
steps.content: Group the terms to form pairs. Group the first two terms into a pair and the second two terms into a pair. [6] X Research source Example: 2x 2 + 5x + 4x + 10 = (2x 2 + 5x) + (4x + 10)

steps.title: Factor out each pair.
steps.content: Factor out each pair. Find the common factors of the pair and factor them out. Rewrite the equation accordingly. [7] X Research source Example: x(2x + 5) + 2(2x + 5)

steps.title: Factor out shared parentheses.
steps.content: Factor out shared parentheses. There should be a shared binomial parentheses between the two halves. Factor this out, and place the other terms in another parentheses. [8] X Research source Example: (2x + 5)(x + 2)

steps.title: Write your answer.
steps.content: Write your answer. You should now have your final answer. [9] X Research source Example: 2x 2 + 9x + 10 = (2x + 5)(x + 2) The final answer is: (2x + 5)(x + 2)

steps.title: Look at the equation.
steps.content: Look at the equation. The equation should have four separate terms. The exact appearance of those four terms can vary, however. [10] X Research source Usually, you will use this method when you see a polynomial equation that looks like: ax 3 + bx 2 + cx + d The equation may also look like: axy + by + cx + d ax 2 + bx + cxy + dy ax 4 + bx 3 + cx 2 + dx Or similar variations. Example: 4x 4 + 12x 3 + 6x 2 + 18x

steps.title: Factor out the greatest common factor (GCF).
steps.content: Factor out the greatest common factor (GCF). Determine if all four terms have anything in common. The greatest common factor among the four terms, if any common factors exist, should be factored out of the equation. [11] X Research source If the only thing all four terms has in common is the number "1," there is no GCF and nothing can be factored out at this point. When you do factor out a GCF, make sure that you continue to keep it at the front of your equation as you work. This factored out GCF must be included as part of your final answer for that answer to be accurate. Example: 4x 4 + 12x 3 + 6x 2 + 18x Each term has 2x in common, so the problem can be rewritten as: 2x(2x 3 + 6x 2 + 3x + 9)

steps.title: Create smaller groups within the problem.
steps.content: Create smaller groups within the problem. Group the first two terms together and the second two terms together. [12] X Research source If the first term of the second group has a minus sign in front of it, you will need to put a minus sign in front of the second parentheses. You will need to change the sign of the second term in that grouping to reflect that choice. Example: 2x(2x 3 + 6x 2 + 3x + 9) = 2x[(2x 3 + 6x 2 ) + (3x + 9)]

steps.title: Factor out the GCF from each binomial.
steps.content: Factor out the GCF from each binomial. Identify the GCF in each binomial pair and factor it to the outside of the pair. Rewrite the equation accordingly. [13] X Research source At this point, you might be faced with a choice between factoring out a positive number or a negative number for the second group. Look at the signs before the second and fourth terms. When the two signs are the same (both positive or both negative), factor out a positive number. When the two signs are different (one negative and one positive), factor out a negative number. Example: 2x[(2x 3 + 6x 2 ) + (3x + 9)] = 2x 2 [2x 2 (x + 3) + 3(x + 3)]

steps.title: Factor out the common binomial.
steps.content: Factor out the common binomial. The binomial pair inside both parentheses should be the same. Factor this out of the equation, then group the remaining terms into another parentheses set. [14] X Research source If the binomials inside the current sets of parentheses do not match, double-check your work or try rearranging your terms and grouping the equation again. The parentheses must match. If they do not match no matter what you try, the problem cannot be factored by grouping or by any other method. Example: 2x 2 [2x 2 (x + 3) + 3(x + 3)] = 2x 2 [(x + 3)(2x 2 + 3)]

steps.title: Write your answer.
steps.content: Write your answer. You should have the final answer at this point. Example: 4x 4 + 12x 3 + 6x 2 + 18x = 2x 2 (x + 3)(2x 2 + 3) The final answer is: 2x 2 (x + 3)(2x 2 + 3)

steps.title: When factoring by grouping, after factoring out the GCF from each group, the binomials in the two sets of parentheses must match up in order to go any further with the problem.
steps.content: When factoring by grouping, after factoring out the GCF from each group, the binomials in the two sets of parentheses must match up in order to go any further with the problem. [15] X Research source
